title: Saudi Arabia’s Markets Weren’t Rattled by the Oil Strike. Here’s Why.
text:
Text size

You might think that not much happened in Saudi Arabia over the past week if you were watching the kingdom’s financial markets.

The iShares MSCI Saudi Arabia exchange-traded fund (ticker: KSA) is up a hair since Sept. 14, when the Abqaiq refinery drone attack knocked out half of the country’s oil production. Yields on Saudi bonds jumped by a percentage point after the attack, then quickly reverted to about 3%. Stocks in the United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia’s closest regional ally, were unmoved.

There are sound technical reasons for the steady performance. Saudi shares had already fallen 15% since early May, as oil prices slipped and enthusiasm around the country’s joining MSCI’s global emerging markets index faded. “Saudi has been on the back foot since the MSCI inclusion,” says Michael Irsaneous, head of Middle East equity sales at emerging markets broker Auerbach Grayson. “It rallied until April, then sold off.”

Global starvation for yield is buoying Saudi bond prices. At 3%, investors already get a risk premium for Riyadh’s sovereign debt. Other countries with similar A ratings, like Chile or Poland, pay about 2.4%, says Edwin Gutierrez, head of emerging markets sovereign debt at Aberdeen Asset Management. When the yield bounced after the bombing, Asian investors leapt in and brought it back down. “This was like the holy grail for Taiwanese guys struggling for return,” he says.

Gutierrez himself remains a buyer of Saudi credit at 3%, betting that it will “converge over time” with its peer group. (Bond prices go up as yields go down.) Ricardo Adrogue, head of emerging markets debt at Barings, begs to differ. Saudi and its Gulf neighbors have gorged on some $150 billion in sovereign debt since 2016, just as tensions between the kingdom and regional rival Iran ratchet up. “We feel smart now for being cautious in a region with such high geopolitical risk,” he says.

Whatever the tactical calculus for investors, the idea that Saudi Arabia can smoothly return to business as usual after Abqaiq evokes a “degree of disbelief,” says Simon Henderson, director of Gulf and energy policy at the Washington Institute.

Riyadh’s 34-year-old leader, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, has a multidecade master plan to diversify the economy beyond oil. The first step was supposed to be raising $100 billion from listing 5% of state crude monopoly Saudi Aramco. The sale will “at the very least need to be repackaged” post-bombing, Henderson says, though Saudi officials vowed to steam ahead.

More speculative is how the attack, and Riyadh’s so-far hesitant response, will affect the prestige of MBS, as the crown prince is known. He acts as his own defense minister and brought in his younger brother as deputy, making it hard to lay blame elsewhere. “The wider royal family probably thinks, ‘What a disaster!’ ” Henderson says.

Investors hunting for bargains on the next round of Middle East volatility should think about Egypt, Irsaneous says. Cairo stocks fell as much as 3.5% after the Abqaiq assault (then bounced back), even though the largest Arab nation is far from the line of fire. Unlike the Gulf petro states, Egypt offers a dynamic domestic story, with growth cruising above 5% annually, and inflation down by half over the past year.

“Most of our investors are overweight Egypt,” Irsaneous says. “This is a market where the fundamentals are very good.”
